|Title=Knowing the indications for performing a myelogram in children
|Description=None
|Topic=Positive diagnosis
|Contributors=Virginie Gandemer
|Order=10}}
'''Impairment of 2 or 3 blood lines'' (anaemia, thrombocytopenia, neutropenia) on the haemogram requires a myelogram before any specific treatment as it suggests a bone marrow cause for the cytopenias. Circulating blastosis is not necessary for a myelogram to be indicated.

This will show > 25% blasts on rich MO in the case of acute leukaemia. This examination should be systematically supplemented by CSF analysis, even in the absence of any neurological symptoms.

SDS link

- Reasoned request/prescription and choice of a diagnostic examination SD-178]]

- Interpretation of an SD-221 myelogram

- Preventing pain in healthcare SD-258

properties.question: When is a myelogram indicated for children with blood cell line impairments?
properties.option_a: Only when there is a presence of circulating blasts greater than 25% in the bone marrow.
properties.option_b: When there are signs of neurological symptoms, regardless of blood cell line impairments.
properties.option_c: When there is impairment of 2 or 3 blood lines (anaemia, thrombocytopenia, neutropenia) on the haemogram, even without circulating blasts.
properties.option_d: Exclusively when CSF analysis shows abnormalities, irrespective of blood cell line impairments.
